essay.body: While violence is imminent in Pietro da Cortona's <em>Saint Martina Refuses to Adore the Idols<em>, it takes center stage in his preliminary sketch for the <em>Age of Iron<em>, one of four frescoes in the Sala della Stufa in the Palazzo Pitti, Aorence-a project commissioned in 1637 by Duke Ferdinando II de' Medici that Cortona completed in 1640. The overall theme of the cycle, the Four Ages of the World, derives from Ovid's <em>Metamorphoses<em>, in which the creation  of the world was followed by four ages: Gold, Silver, Bronze, and Iron. The Iron age was characterized  by greed, pillage, and murÂ­der, which Cortona  spotlights  in  the foreground  of his flurried  composition, where a soldier raises his sword against a defenseless woman  and her children. In the background, another  soldier attacks a Christian priest, identified as such by the small crucifixes indicated at the left margin. This anachronism is corrected in the fresco itself, where the statue of a goddess under a portico identifies the building as a pagan temple.
